person.note: WGE 3 mentions a city in Capadocia named ̓́Αβλατα, but this is hardly likely to be the intended name here. This is more likely a transliteration of the Semitic עבלאדה. It appears to me that this reflects a letter reversal as the result of a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.3, p. 20 and should read עבדאלה. On such transliterations see Introduction 2.1.
So according to the owner of this inscription.

This inscription was presumably found in Hebron. It mentions the biblical Abraham, Isaac and Aaron. It could be Jewish but is could of course just as likely be Christian, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
The name transliterated is probably עבדאלגי, see Introduction 2.1.2.
In Greek – ἀποθανόντας ἐτῶν ο ́. On such details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21.
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
The inscription is dated according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.
The fall of the α is probably a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.2, p. 20.

note.ref: See above, n. 4. The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
See above, n. 5. The inscription is dated according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.

person.note: In Greek – ἐτων πε ́. On such details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21.

note.ref: See above, n. 4. The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
See above, n. 5. The inscription is dated according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.

person.note: I reconstructed the name.

note.ref: See above, n. 4. The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
See above, n. 5. The inscription is dated according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.

person.note: The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
The inscription is dated according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.
In Greek – ἐτῶν ξ ́. On such details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21.
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
The inscription is dated according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.
In Greek – ἔτη α ́. On such details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21.
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
The inscription is dated according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.
The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.3.1, p. 35.
Because so many of the inscriptions from Zoar are dated, it is easy to date the others approximately, see Introduction 7.5.2.3.
The inscription is reconstructed by the editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11.
In Greek – [ἐτῶ]ν ν ́.On such details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21.

The inscription mentions the formula: εἱς Θεός̔ μόνος (God is one and only). This, however, especially in Zoar, is no indication of Jewishness, see Introduction 6.1.6. The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
Because so many of the inscriptions from Zoar are dated, it is easy to date the others approximately, see Introduction 7.5.2.3.
The inscription was identified by CIJ as Jewish due to a misunderstanding, and see IJO 3, p. 236.
In another inscription, from this cemetery, he is mentioned, still alive, at this date, see IJO 3, p. 236, and Introduction 7.1.
In Transjordan.
Jewishness suggested based on son’s name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. The location is also not particularly Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.6.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
The inscription is reconstructed by the editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11.
In Greek – λατ[όμος].
In the Golan.
The λ in this name is not clear. Perhaps the title חזן was intended, see Introduction 3.1.2.2 (suggested by Anna Veronese).
The inscription is reconstructed by the editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11.
In the Golan.
Jewishness suggested based on father’s name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
The editor identified the inscription as Jewish because it was found in proximity to the synagogue in Hamat Tiberias, but this is inconclusive, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.3, p. 38.
In Greek – ̔ ἰατρ(ός). On such designations Introduction 3.1.3.3.
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.
The name appears in two epitaphs, in an unusual location, perhaps indicating the family relationship between the two.

It was assumed by the editor that a name with the elements עבד and ברוך must be Jewish, but this is not necessary, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.2, p. 51. IJO 3, App13 did not include it in their corpus.
The inscription is dated according to the Seleucid era, see Introduction 7.5.4.1.
So in BS 2:118. In BS 12:116 and BS 2:120 the reading is reconstructed (̓Ενε[βήλου]; ̓Ενη[βήλου]).
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.
On such nicknames see vol. 1, Introduction 6.1.1, p. 46.
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
The inscription is dated according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.
I read this as dative and male. The editors read it as nominative female, but since the male Thinos exists I take this to be the same name.
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.
Town east of Tel Aviv.

Jewishness suggested based on son’s name but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. The region was not particularly Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.6. The editor suggested that the title too was Jewish, but there is no evidence that this title was reserved for Jews rather than Christians or Samaritans.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.
In Greek – ἠτῶν γ ́. On such details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21.
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
Because so many of the inscriptions from Zoar are dated, it is easy to date the others approximately, see Introduction 7.5.2.3.
In Greek – ἐτῶν με ́. On such details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21.
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
Because so many of the inscriptions from Zoar are dated, it is easy to date the others approximately, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.
In Greek – Βουλα(υτοῦ). It is not clear whether this title refers to him or to his son, whose name is not preserved in the inscription. On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.4.
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
Because so many of the inscriptions from Zoar are dated, it is easy to date the others approximately, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.
So in inscription 6.
So in inscription 7.
The editors identified this as a designation: “cage maker.”
The inscription is reconstructed by the editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11.
Described in the text as [συμ]φυλευς (fellow countryman?) of a certain Isaac (62), whose Jewishness may be suggested based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.9, p. 53..

The early editors of the Jewish inscriptions from Jaffa suggested this date for them, see Introduction 5.2.2.1. If the date is correct for the other Jaffa inscriptions, it is correct for this one as well.
On such nicknames see vol. 1, Introduction 6.1.1, p. 46.
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
Because so many of the inscriptions from Zoar are dated, it is easy to date the others approximately, see Introduction 7.5.2.3.
On the northern shore of the Sea of Galilee.
On such nicknames see vol. 1, Introduction 6.1.1, p. 46.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
Because so many of the inscriptions from Zoar are dated, it is easy to date the others approximately, see Introduction 7.5.2.3.
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
The inscription is dated according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.

The inscription includes the formula Εἱς Θεός (one God), but this is not a uniquely Jewish phenomenon, especially not in Zoar, see Introduction 6.1.6. The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
The inscription is dated according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.
In Greek – ἐτῶν πέν[τ]ε. On such details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21.
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
The inscription is dated according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.
The inscription is bilingual – Greek and Latin. So in the Greek.
The inscription is bilingual – Greek and Latin. So in the Latin.

In Greek – Κανωθαι[́ω]ν ἐπ[ὶ]Συρίης. In Latin – Septimiano Canotha (Septimiana being the Latin name of the town). Canatha is situated in Transjordan. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34.

Oehler, MGWJ53 (1909) 449 writes “vielleicht ein Jude” probably based on the fact that he came to Gaul from Syria and had a Semitic name, but both criteria are not decisive. CIJ thought he was a pagan.
The name of the town “[S]eptimiano,” is after the emperor Septimius Severus. This is the year in which he died, see Introduction 7.1.
The name transliterated is probably סועד, see Introduction 2.1.2.1.
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
Because so many of the inscriptions from Zoar are dated, it is easy to date the others approximately, see Introduction 7.5.2.3.
So in Malalas.
So in Procopius.
His son is described by Malalas as Σαμαρείτην (a Samaritan), see Introduction 6.1.1.
Was a contemporary of the emperor Justinian. These are his dates, see Introduction 7.1.
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
Because so many of the inscriptions from Zoar are dated, it is easy to date the others approximately, see Introduction 7.5.2.3.
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
The inscription is dated according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.

Reading is mine, based on the drawing of the inscription published, see Introduction 2.4. The editor offered the reading “Theotiokos” (mother of God?), which I do not see, and would hardly be a name of a Samaritan man.
West of Nablus (Sichem).
This is a Samaritan synagogue, see Introduction 6.1.4.

In Jewish characters this would read פצלס. The fall of the second α is probably a scribal error, see vol. 3, introduction 2.8.2, p. 20. On the interchange of η and ε see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.3.2, p. 22. The suffix is unusual, but see Introduction 2.1.1. The editors identified this as a female name because they understood the suffix as a corrupted female genitive ης. However, since this is a Semitic name with the theophoric אל suffix, which is not known to be female in Semitic languages, I find this interpretation unlikely.

The inscription includes the verse Ps 23:1, according to the Septuagint. This could be perceived as Christian, because the Septuagint by this time was no longer in use by Jews, but there is no other Christian indication, and since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
Because so many of the inscriptions from Zoar are dated, it is easy to date the others approximately, see Introduction 7.5.2.3.
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
The inscription is dated according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.
For the problems of the Jewishness of persons recorded in this location see Appendix 4.3.
On the dating of the Greek inscriptions in Elijah’s Cave see Appendix 3.1.
The early editors of the Jewish inscriptions from Jaffa suggested this date for them. If the date is correct for the other Jaffa inscriptions, it is correct for this one as well.

The inscription is not published It is reported to be in Latin and to represent this name, but it was not seen by professional epigraphists and could have been wrongly read, see Introduction 2.4. It could actually have been written in Greek.
This was suggested based on the location and nature of the find, but see Introduction 6.1.5.1.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

div.note: In vol. 4 this name is recorded under Arabic names عبد الله (see p. 286).The name עבדאללה is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 791. The form ‘BD’LH is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 397
The name עבדאלגא is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 788. The name transliterated is probably עבדאלגו, see Introduction 1.6.2.
The name עבדחרתת is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 802. The name transliterated is probably עבדוחרתא, see Introduction 1.6.2.

On Arabic names beginning with ‘BD see Harding, ICPIANI, 400-2. On such Nabatean names see Negev, Qedem32, nos. 782-827. On such Palmyran names see Stark, PNPI, 41-2. This name or one like it is not recorded. The name transliterated is probably עבדואלמיתבו, see Introduction 1.6.2.
The name ‘BDMNT is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 400. The name transliterated is probably עבדומני, see Introduction 1.6.2.
The name ‘BDMK is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 400. The name transliterated is probably עבדומכו, see Introduction 1.6.2.

The name ‘BDŠMSM is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 399. The name ‘ABDŠMY’ is recorded for Palmyrans, see Stark, PNPI, 42. The name transliterated is probably עבדושימאו, see Introduction 1.6.2.

On Arabic names beginning with ‘BD see Harding, ICPIANI, 396-402. On such Nabatean names see Negev, Qedem32, nos. 782-827. On such Palmyran names see Stark, PNPI, 41-2. This name or one like it is not recorded. The name transliterated is probably עבדרבשא, see Introduction 2.1.2.1. On the use of ψ for this purpose see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.2.7, p. 19.

עזיז means “strong, intense” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1061). The name עזיזו is recorded for Edomeans (AOFCI, 46) and Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 869). The form ’ZZ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 418). The form ‘ZYZ is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 44). In vol. 4, this is recorded as an Arabic name, see p. 289.
The form ’LZN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 66). The name transliterated is probably אלזן, see Introduction 2.1.2.1.
The form ’LWD is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 72). The name transliterated is probably אלוד, see Introduction 2.1.2.1.

ברסם means “a dripping like balsam” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 196). The form BRṢM is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 72). The form BRSMY’ is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 12). The name transliterated is probably ברסמותי, see Introduction 2.1.2.1. On the בר prefix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.1.2.1, p. 18.
The form BQNH is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 114). The name transliterated is probably בקנו, see Introduction 2.1.2.1.

ביזא means “rag, wreck” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 160). The form BZY is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 9). The Semitic name intended is probably ביזו, see Introduction 2.1.2.1. However, note that WGE 3 mentions a city in Thrace named Βιζύη.

On Arabic names beginning with ‘BD see Harding, ICPIANI, 396-402. On such Nabatean names see Negev, Qedem32, nos. 782-827. This name, or one like it, is not recorded. The name transliterated is probably עבידברוך, see Introduction 2.1.2.1.

This is the Greek rendering of the name of the famous Carthaginian general Hannibal, (WGE, 92). The name ḤNBL is recorded in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 23. For a similar name see vol. 1, under Hannibaal S-G/M, p. 430. The Semitic form transliterated here would be חנבל, see Introduction 2.1.2.1.
The form ZDQL is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 19). The name transliterated is probably זדקומו, see Introduction 2.1.2.1.
The name תימרצו is recorded for persons from Palmyra in vol. 4, under Timarṣu S-H/M, p. 404. The name transliterated is probably תימריצא, see Introduction 2.1.2.
The word θῖνος means “sacred” in the Cretan Greek dialect, see Liddell & Scott, Dictionary, 801. BS 2, p. 55, n. 146, suggests that the name derives from the Hebrew תאנה (fig).
תותא means “mulberry” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1659). The form TT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 128). The name transliterated is probably תותא, see Introduction 2.1.2.1.
The name YLF is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 682. The name transliterated is probably יולפו, see Introduction 1.6.2.
The name קשתו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1042, and it is probably the name transliterated here, see Introduction 1.6.2.
The name ‘QSS is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 482. The name transliterated is probably קשישו, see Introduction 2.1.2.
The forms QLB/KLB are recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 486, 502). The form QLYBW is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 48). This could transliterate a Semitic כלוב, see Introduction 2.1.2.1.
The name QRYNW is recorded for Palmyrans, see Stark, PNPI, 49. The name transliterated is probably קורנן, see Introduction 2.1.2.1.
The name קוזא is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1010. The name transliterated is probably קוזון, see Introduction 2.1.2.1.

לולב means “sprout” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 698). Cf. also yOrl 2:1, 61d (לוליבא which is probably לוליאני, see under Lulianus [1]). The form LLB is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 520). The name transliterated is probably לולב, see Introduction 2.1.2.1.
The name MZBN’ is recorded in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 31. The name transliterated is probably מזבנו, see Introduction 1.6.2.
Jastrow, DTTBYML, 806 describes מסימיס as “a popular corruption of semissis – a Roman value, equal to half an as or six ounces.”
The name NMS is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 600. The name transliterated is probably נמו, see Introduction 1.6.2.
The name עבת is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 838. The name transliterated is probably אובותו, see Introduction 2.1.2.
The name ‘JZ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 408). The name transliterated is probably אוגזון, see Introduction 2.1.2.
The name והבן is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 343), and this is the name probably transliterated here, see Introduction 2.1.2.

סעד means “support, auxiliary” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1009). The form S‘D is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 318). This would transliterate a Semitic name such as סעד, see Introduction 2.1.2.1.

The forms SBR/ṢBR are recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 309, 366). The name צברו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 990, and this is probably the name transliterated here, see Introduction 2.1.2.1
The name שמשו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1163), and this is probably the name transliterated here, see Introduction 1.6.2.
On Arabic names beginning with ŠMR see Harding, ICPIANI, 357-8. On such Nabatean names see Negev, Qedem32, nos. 1157-9. The name transliterated is probably שמיראבו, see Introduction 1.6.2.
For some names no etymology or parallel was found. This is one of them, and see next note.

This is a Hebrew theophoric name (ηλ=אל). פצי/פצא means “to open” or “to deliver, save” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1204). The name פצאל was used in the Nabatean royal family (e.g. CIS II.I no. 354/3). It is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 468), for Nabateans, (Negev, Qedem 32, no 970) and in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 109). For Jews the name is recorded only in Greek.

For some names no etymology or parallel was found. This is one of them. It may be some variation on a Greek theophoric name with the element θέος (God). The name transliterated is probably פינתאו, see Introduction 1.6.2.
In WGE, 1633, the name as such is identified as Egyptian.
The form ḤLBT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 197). The form KLBY is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 29). The name transliterated is probably כולבידיה, see Introduction 2.1.2.1.
For some names no etymology or parallel was found. This is one of them.
